fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Intuitively, 1/(z-a) is the derivative of the function \log (z - a). But formalizing this is difficult, since logarithms are not single-valued, so what happens near the branch cuts is not clear. However, we can avoid this by considering the inverse function \exp instead.

Let the path be parametrized by the interval [0,1] for convenience. Consider the function g(t) = \int _0^t \frac {\gamma '(t)}{\gamma (t) - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {t}. By the intuition above, we expect g(t) \xlongequal {?} \log (\gamma (t) - a) + C. So we instead consider h(t) = \exp (g(t))/(\gamma (t) - a) and prove it is a constant. This can be verified by differentiation, using the chain rule and the fundamental theorem of calculus.

Of course, \gamma is only piecewise differentiable. So h(t) is only constant on each piece. But in addition, h(t) is continuous on the entire curve, so it must be globally constant. Moreover, since \gamma is a loop, we have \gamma (0) = \gamma (1), and since h(0) = h(1), we can deduce 1 = \exp (g(0)) = \exp (g(1)), which means the integral g(1) is a multiple of 2 \pi i as desired.
Given a piecewise differentiable closed curve \gamma not passing through a, the complex line integral \int _\gamma \frac {1}{z - a} \operatorname {d}\mathclose {z} is always a multiple of 2 \pi i.
